Award.AbstractNarration:
Yam is a major source of dietary starch for smallholder farm families in many tropical and sub-tropical countries. Despite its global importance, use of modern genomics tools that can facilitate the fundamental understanding of how to increase yam productivity and nutritional quality has lagged behind that of other major crops. The overall goal of this project is to address this missed opportunity and establish robust genetic and genomic resources for yams. The ultimate beneficiaries of these genome-enabled platforms for crop improvement are the female farmers who depend on yams for their livelihoods.

This project will develop effective tools for the fundamental understanding and genetic improvement of yam (Dioscorea rotundata), an important African staple crop. The specific objectives include (1) establishing an efficient genome editing platform using a clustered regularly interspaced short palindromic repeats/CRISPR associated protein 9 (CRISPR/Cas9) based site-directed mutagenesis system; and, (2) producing and characterizing CRISPR/Cas9-mutagenized yam plants. In addition to providing research training of postdoctoral associates and students, the project will develop and organize a two-week study abroad course in cooperation with IITA-Tanzania to provide Iowa State University undergraduate students practical exposure to the needs and opportunities in global agricultural research. The project will also provide short-term laboratory training experience for African female scientists as well as conduct a focused workshop at the International Institute of Tropical Agriculture (IITA-Kenya) to share the latest transformation developments and genome editing protocols with African scientists. All genome-enabled resource for yams, including vectors, methods and plant materials, generated in this project will be distributed through the Iowa State University Center for Plant Transformation and IITA-Kenya.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Yam is a major source of dietary starch for smallholder farm families in many tropical and sub-tropical countries. The overall goal of this proposed project is to establish genome-enabled platforms for yam, so it can be used for both basic and applied research for yam improvement. Five specific objectives were proposed and the outcomes are summarized here.

1. CRISPR-based genome-editing system for yam: We have established an efficient protocol for yam protoplast isolation and transfection. Using this protocol with a reporter system, we have identified a suitable promoter for expression of Cas9 and two U6 promoters to activate the guide RNA genes ? a CRISPR/Cas9 platform for genome editing in yam. Based on the platform, three sets of CRISPR constructs have been designed and created to test the feasibility of system with stable transgenics in yam. We also established an Agrobacterium leaf infiltration system for yam that can be used for future validation of CRISPR constructs. Finally, a transformation enhancer system based on morphogenic genes has been established and validated in maize, will be applied in yam to improve the genetic transformation and enable genome editing of yam.

2. Producing targeted-mutagenized yam plants: This grant allowed us to optimize a previously established yam transformation protocol. Using the improved protocol, we obtained six kanamycin resistant transgenic yam plants. For generating targeted mutagenesis on phytoene desaturase (PDS) gene in yam, we made a couple of constructs carrying validated gRNAs and Cas9. Three albino mutant plants were produced. Sanger sequencing analysis confirmed that they carry the expected indel mutations at the target site.

3. Training of African woman scientist: One African woman scientist spent one summer month in Iowa State University receiving training on genome editing technology.  A Kenyan female graduate student has been trained for genome editing of yam.  She finished her Ph.D. thesis research under this project.

4. Hands-on workshop for African scientists: A two-day focus workshop entitled ?CRISPR/Cas-mediated Plant Genome Editing: From Design to Analysis? was held in ILRI (International Livestock Research Institute) Campus in Nairobi, Kenya on genome-editing was held in IITA-Kenya on June 18 & 19, 2018. This is the first hands-on workshop on plant genome editing in Africa. A total of 30 scientists from five African countries participated in the workshop and learnt techniques of CRISPR design, DNA construct preparation, and yam/banana transformation.

5. Undergrad study abroad course: An undergraduate study abroad course for enhancing students global experience in tropic agriculture was taken place in May of 2018. This two-week experience in Costa Rica exposed a group of plant science major undergrad and graduate students with a wide range of crops and cropping systems, including yams. They had the opportunity for direct and personal interaction with local research scientists, farm managers, farmers, and student peers. Students visited university and private research stations, research labs at the University of Costa Rica, and numerous small and industrial-scale agricultural production programs across the country.
